title: Plotting the Future of the Most Storied Studio in Jazz
abstract: The New Jersey recording space built in 1959 by Rudy Van Gelder is filled with history. Can it regain its glory without getting stuck in the past?

multimedia.copyright: Vincent Tullo for The New York Times
Vincent Tullo for The New York Times

title: ‘History Is Everything’: Making a Film About Black Maternal Mortality
abstract: The directors Paula Eiselt and Tonya Lewis Lee discuss their journey in making the documentary “Aftershock,” which shines a light on a national health crisis.

multimedia.caption: Shawnee Benton Gibson and Bruce McIntyre, at right, are central figures in the documentary “Aftershock,” about the abmysal death rates of Black mothers in the United States.

title: The Unraveling of an Award-Winning Documentary
abstract: The director of “Sabaya,” about Yazidi women who had been sexually enslaved by ISIS, says that he wasn’t present for a key scene and that he substituted footage.
des_facet: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

multimedia.caption: A scene from “Sabaya,” directed by Hogir Hirori, about Yazidi women freed from a detention camp for families of ISIS fighters.

title: Claes Oldenburg Dies at 93; Pop Artist Made the Everyday Monumental
abstract: Taking ordinary objects like hamburgers and household items, he sculpted them in unfamiliar, often imposing dimensions — what he called his “Colossal Monuments.”

multimedia.caption: “Spoonbridge and Cherry” at the Minneapolis Sculpture Garden.

title: When Making a Salad Felt Radical
abstract: Ahead of her retrospective in Berkeley, Calif., the artist Alison Knowles talks about her Fluxus roots, the appeal of beans and the power of interactive artworks.
org_facet: Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive

multimedia.caption: Since performing in early Fluxus concerts in the ’60s, Alison Knowles has made decades of inviting artwork. “I don’t want people looking passively at my work but actively participating by touching, eating” and more, she said from her SoHo studio.
multimedia.copyright: Lila Barth for The New York Times

title: Jawole Willa Jo Zollar Wins Gish Prize
abstract: Zollar, founder of the dance ensemble Urban Bush Women, will receive a cash award of $250,000 for pushing the boundaries of art and contributing to social change.

multimedia.caption: Jawole Willa Jo Zollar has “brought movement vocabularies inspired by African traditions into the canon,” said the leader of the Gish Prize’s selection committee, adding that Zollar is a “trailblazer.”

title: ‘Heart’ Review: First a Starter Marriage, Then Real Love
abstract: In her new autobiographical solo play, the actress Jade Anouka recounts the joys and fears of falling for a woman after her marriage to a man ends.

multimedia.caption: The actress and writer Jade Anouka in her autobiographical solo play, “Heart,” at the Minetta Lane Theater in Manhattan.

title: Kodak Black Is Arrested on Drug Charges in Florida
abstract: The authorities said they found dozens of oxycodone tablets and $75,000 in cash while searching the rapper’s car after he was pulled over in Fort Lauderdale on Friday.

abstract: Does poetry have any place in a war zone? For one correspondent, it is indispensable.

title: The Echoes and Echoes and Echoes of War
abstract: In his new story collection, “The Haunting of Hajji Hotak,” Jamil Jan Kochai explores the intergenerational impact of conflict.

title: ‘Late Show’ Staff Arrested at U.S. Capitol Complex Won’t Be Prosecuted
abstract: The Justice Department said it would not proceed with charges of unlawful entry against staff members from “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert” who were arrested at a Capitol building last month.
des_facet: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)

multimedia.caption: When members of the “Late Show” staff were detained at the U.S. Capitol complex, they had been filming a segment featuring Triumph the Insult Comic Dog, a puppet voiced by Robert Smigel.

title: An ‘Impossible Dream’ Comes True, Again, for Marylouise Burke in ‘Epiphany’
abstract: The 81-year-old actress stars as an eccentric dinner party host. When she was a teenager, though, wanting to act was a secret she didn’t dare tell.

multimedia.caption: “I actually knew probably from the time I was 13 or 14 that I wanted to act,” said Marylouise Burke, who has been performing on New York stages since 1973. “But it seemed like such an impossible dream.”
multimedia.copyright: Celeste Sloman for The New York Times

title: Love the Smell of Old Books? This Bookseller Would Like You to Leave.
abstract: In his grouchy, funny memoir, “A Factotum in the Book Trade,” Marius Kociejowski writes about what a good bookstore should feel like, famous customers he’s served and more.
des_facet: A Factotum in the Book Trade (Book)

title: The Jewish Deli: An American Tale Told in Pickles and Pastrami
abstract: “I’ll Have What She’s Having,” a traveling exhibit on the Jewish delicatessen, looks back at a vibrant institution fueled by immigration and irresistible food.

multimedia.caption: The challenge of a museum exhibition on cuisine: conveying taste and smell in a gallery where food is not allowed. This attempt to fabricate a corned beef sandwich created a bit of a crisis for curators.
multimedia.copyright: Joel Barhamand for The New York Times

title: Jennifer Lopez and Ben Affleck Have a Low-Key Midnight Wedding in Las Vegas
abstract: The superstar couple, who got back together last year, waited in line and went to a chapel that Lopez said “graciously stayed open” a few minutes past midnight so they could wed.

title: Billy Crystal’s ‘Mr. Saturday Night’ Will End Its Broadway Run
abstract: The stage musical, adapted from a 1992 film, will close Labor Day weekend after five months at the Nederlander Theater.

title: Lend Me a Jukebox Opera. Yuks and Tenor Required.
abstract: “Let’s do a Rossini comedy that doesn’t exist yet,” the head of the Glimmerglass Festival said. Coming soon: Ken Ludwig’s “Tenor Overboard.”

title: Peeling Paint in Hong Kong Reveals Work of Newly Relevant ‘King’
abstract: When he was alive, the graffiti of Tsang Tsou-choi, or the “King of Kowloon,” was considered peculiar and personal. In a radically changed city, his mostly vanished art now has a political charge.

multimedia.caption: When work by the graffiti artist Tsang Tsou-choi re-emerged beneath a Hong Kong bridge, the mundane setting became an unlikely attraction in a city where dissent has been stamped out.
multimedia.copyright: Anthony Kwan for The New York Times

title: A Crop of New Novels About Race and Racism Finds Freedom in Satire
abstract: Authors of color have turned in recent books to humor and surreal conceits to explore racism, identity politics and the pain of being “on the other side of whiteness.”

multimedia.caption: “Many white writers have had the privilege or power of writing another culture,” said Chinelo Okparanta, the author of “Harry Sylvester Bird.” “I wanted to see what it would look like for me to write about a culture that I don’t know.”
multimedia.copyright: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: “Many white writers have had the privilege or power of writing another culture,” said Chinelo Okparanta, the author of “Harry Sylvester Bird.” “I wanted to see what it would look like for me to write about a culture that I don’t know.”

title: In Rome, a New Museum for Recovered Treasures Before They Return Home
abstract: The Museum of Rescued Art showcases antiquities that were looted or otherwise lost before they go back to institutions in the regions from which they were taken.

multimedia.caption: The Museum of Rescued Art in Rome, which opened last month, is focusing attention on the many art works that have been salvaged, some from natural disasters and others from thieves.
multimedia.copyright: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times

title: Jak Knight, Known for the Netflix Series ‘Big Mouth,’ Dies at 28
abstract: Mr. Knight, who had been a successful stand-up comedian for several years, was also a writer for the ABC sitcom “Black-ish.”

title: Mark Fleischman, the Last Impresario of Studio 54, Dies at 82
abstract: He took over the celebrated Manhattan club in the early 1980s and briefly became the self-described “ringleader” of an all-night circus.

multimedia.caption: Mark Fleischman in 1993, a decade after he owned the famed disco Studio 54. “I was thoroughly seduced,” he said, “by the idea of controlling the world’s most important nightclub.”

title: David Dalton, Rock Writer Who Lived the Scene, Dies at 80
abstract: An early writer for Rolling Stone, he traveled in the same circles as the Beatles, Janis Joplin and other stars, witnessing and documenting a time of cultural transformation.

title: The Knights of Medieval Times Will Carry Union Cards With Their Lances
